title: Mihai Teja
text:
Mihai Răzvan Teja (born 22 September 1978) is a Romanian professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> and former player.
Club career.
After Teja finished his youth years at <a href="FC%20Steaua%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Steaua București</a> and was starting to be integrated into the first team squad, he was diagnosed with <a href="Wolff%E2%80%93Parkinson%E2%80%93White%20syndrome">Wolff–Parkinson–White syndrome</a>, a heart disorder that did not allow him to play professional sports, thus he had to put and end to his playing career without making a single appearance.
Coaching career.
Teja decided to finish his studies and got a <a href="master%27s%20degree">master's degree</a> and a <a href="doctorate">doctorate</a> at the <a href="National%20University%20of%20Physical%20Education%20and%20Sport">National University of Physical Education and Sport</a>. While at college, he returned to football and joined <a href="FC%20Dinamo%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Dinamo București</a>, where he became youth coach at the club's academy. While there, he met <a href="Walter%20Zenga">Walter Zenga</a>, who recommended him to <a href="Centro%20Tecnico%20Federale%20di%20Coverciano">Coverciano</a>, where he got degrees as a football manager and a fitness coach.
After Coverciano, he returned to Dinamo, where he was assistant manager at the second team of the club. In 2006, Teja began a collaboration with <a href="Mircea%20Rednic">Mircea Rednic</a>, helping him as assistant and fitness coach at <a href="FC%20Vaslui">FC Vaslui</a> and <a href="FC%20Dinamo%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Dinamo București</a>. After that he moved to <a href="FC%20Steaua%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Steaua București</a>, where he was the assistant coach of <a href="Marius%20L%C4%83c%C4%83tu%C8%99">Marius Lăcătuș</a>, <a href="Dorinel%20Munteanu">Dorinel Munteanu</a> and <a href="Cristiano%20Bergodi">Cristiano Bergodi</a>.
In 2010, after <a href="Ilie%20Dumitrescu">Ilie Dumitrescu</a> was named the head coach of Steaua and came with his own technical staff, Teja left the club and was reunited with Mircea Rednic, at <a href="FK%20Khazar%20Lankaran">Khazar Lankaran</a>. They returned to Romania in 2012, at <a href="FC%20Petrolul%20Ploie%C8%99ti">Petrolul Ploiești</a>, and then they moved to Belgium, at <a href="Standard%20Li%C3%A8ge">Standard Liège</a>. In 2013, Teja separated from Rednic and joined <a href="FC%20Astra%20Giurgiu">Astra Giurgiu</a>, under the management of <a href="Daniel%20Is%C4%83il%C4%83">Daniel Isăilă</a>.
Managerial career.
He made his debut as head coach at the <a href="Liga%20I">Liga I</a> side <a href="FC%20Universitatea%20Cluj">Universitatea Cluj</a> in October 2013. He ended his contract in September 2014.
In November 2014, Teja was appointed head coach of the <a href="Romania%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Romania national under-21 team</a>. He managed the team for a friendly game against <a href="Serbia%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Serbia U21</a>, in Belgrade, won by Romania 1–0. After only one game in charge, he ended his contract with the <a href="Romanian%20Football%20Federation">Romanian Football Federation</a>. In January 2015, Teja signed a contract with Dinamo București, but was sacked only two months later.
In December 2018, after a good first half of the season with <a href="CS%20Gaz%20Metan%20Media%C8%99">Gaz Metan Mediaș</a>, Teja accepted a one and a half year contract offer from <a href="FCSB">FCSB</a>, following the departure of former coach <a href="Nicolae%20Dic%C4%83">Nicolae Dică</a>.
On 9 January 2020, Teja replaced <a href="Cristiano%20Bergodi">Bergodi</a> as the head coach of <a href="Liga%20I">Liga I</a> side <a href="FC%20Voluntari">Voluntari</a>.
